title: Test
text: Shrubs in the Pacific Northwest occupy an essential niche in both natural and human-influenced environments. This region offers an ideal setting for a wide variety of native and introduced shrub species.

title: Test
text:
Role in Permaculture
In permaculture designs, shrubs are key elements that enhance ecosystem diversity, resilience, and sustainability. They contribute in numerous vital ways:

Microclimate Regulation
Shrubs help to create and modulate microclimates within gardens and landscapes. Their varied heights and densities offer shade and wind protection, moderating soil and air temperatures around them.


Soil Health Improvement
Shrubs contribute to soil health by preventing erosion and improving soil structure through their extensive root systems. The decomposition of leaf litter and woody material from shrubs adds organic matter to the soil, enriching it with nutrients.


Biodiversity Enhancement
Shrubs provide crucial habitats and food sources for a wide array of wildlife, including birds, insects, and small mammals. This supports pollination, pest control, and contributes to a balanced and dynamic ecosystem.

title: Test
text:
Role in Landscape Design
Shrubs offer structural diversity, aesthetic beauty, and functional benefits in landscape design:

Visual and Sensory Appeal
Shrubs bring a variety of forms, colors, textures, and fragrances to gardens and landscapes. They can serve as attractive focal points, hedges, borders, and background plantings, offering year-round visual interest.


Energy Efficiency
Properly placed shrubs can reduce energy costs by providing cooling shade in the summer and acting as windbreaks in the winter, thereby reducing the heating and cooling needs of adjacent buildings.


Privacy and Screening
Shrubs are effective for creating privacy screens and reducing noise pollution, making them invaluable in both residential and urban settings.


Wildlife Gardens
Incorporating native shrubs into landscape designs can create vibrant wildlife gardens, attracting pollinators and birds, and providing shelter and food for various species.

title: Test
text:
Role in the Ecosystem
Beyond their value to humans, shrubs play foundational roles in the broader ecosystem of the Willamette Valley:

Soil Conservation
The root systems of shrubs stabilize the soil, preventing erosion, particularly in vulnerable areas such as slopes and riparian zones.


Ecological Connectivity
Shrubs form essential layers in forested areas and open landscapes, providing connectivity and transition habitats that support wildlife movement and biodiversity.

title: Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List
text:
import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)


#Load data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df.index.name = None 


#images for shade tolerance
ground_cover_shade_images = {
    'Full sun':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Partial sun':'/images/full-sun.png',
    'Full shade':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Full sun/Partial sun':'/images/full-sun-partial-sun.png',
    'Partial sun/Full shade':'/images/partial-sun-full-shade.png'
}

#images for columns that need checks
check_image = {
    'yes':'/images/check.png',
    'no' : ' ',
    'unknown' : 'Unknown'
}

#map images to Sun/Shade column
df['Sun/Shade'] = df['Sun/Shade'].map(ground_cover_shade_images)

# Convert image paths to HTML <img> tags
df['Sun/Shade'] = df['Sun/Shade'].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />')


# Apply the function to each column that needs to be checked
for column in ['Native', 'Medicinal', 'Nitrogen fixer', 'Insect/Bee/Birds']:
    df[column] = df[column].map(check_image)
    df[column] = df[column].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />' if x == '/images/check.png' else x)


display(HTML(df.to_html(escape=False)))

Young leaves edible as steamed or stir fry vegetable, tasty delicate flavor, also good for tea. Chinese make a tonic soup by mixing the bark with chicken or pork. Leaf tea is popular for boosting the immune system, maintaining normal blood pressure levels and strengthening legs and lower back. The bark contains the compound pinoresinal diglucoside, an agent that effectively lowers early stage high blood pressure. Bark also highly regarded to treat osteoporosis and osteoarthritis, slows and may even reverse joint degeneration, reputed to strengthen bones and ligaments (connective tissues in joints). Bark used for various other illnesses in traditional Chinese medicine. Research indicates that the leaves should be interchangeable medicinally with the bark due to their comparable chemistry. Leaves used in Chinese folk medicine as an anti-fungal to treat ringworm and ahtlete feet. Winged fruit (seed) yield 27% oil used for miscellaneous industrial purposes. Bark contains about 3% rubber b y dry weight. This solid latex, called gutta percha, is used to insulate electric cables, etc. but extraction is difficult. wood is used for furniture, fuel, etc. and tends to sucker when cut (coppice).

title: About
text:
This project was created as a resource for the editorial team for editing technical documentation. For more information, please reach out to the editorial team.


Alex Dallman is an editor and developer at the Urban Institute. Before working at Urban, she was the lead academic editor for TypeRight Editing. She received her BA in integrative physiology from the University of Colorado, Boulder, has completed editing courses from the University of Chicago Graham School, and received a graduate-level professional certificate in data analytics from the University of Oregon.

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)


#Load data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Berries")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df.index.name = None 


#images for shade tolerance
ground_cover_shade_images = {
    'Full sun':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Partial sun':'/images/full-sun.png',
    'Full shade':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Full sun/Partial sun':'/images/full-sun-partial-sun.png',
    'Partial sun/Full shade':'/images/partial-sun-full-shade.png'
}

#images for columns that need checks
check_image = {
    'yes':'/images/check.png',
    'no' : ' ',
    'unknown' : 'Unknown'
}

#map images to Sun/Shade column
df['Sun/Shade'] = df['Sun/Shade'].map(ground_cover_shade_images)

# Convert image paths to HTML <img> tags
df['Sun/Shade'] = df['Sun/Shade'].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />')


# Apply the function to each column that needs to be checked
for column in ['Native', 'Medicinal', 'Nitrogen fixer', 'Insect/Bee/Birds']:
    df[column] = df[column].map(check_image)
    df[column] = df[column].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />' if x == '/images/check.png' else x)


display(HTML(df.to_html(escape=False)))

title: R and Git for Editors
section: What Are R, LaTeX, and Quarto?
text:
What Are R, LaTeX, and Quarto?
In research institutions like the Urban Institute, R, LaTeX, and Quarto are powerful tools used together or seperately to produce research products efficiency, with reproducibility and presentation in mind. They are all opensource and free to the public at all levels. Described below is how each piece of the puzzle fits together.

R, RMarkdown, and RStudio

R
R is a programming language used for data analysis and visualization. It was created by statisticians to make the pipeline from raw data to clean visualization and analysis possible.


Analyze data. R helps researchers process and organize datasets, perform statistical analyses, and draw insights from the data.
Visualize results. R can access different types of software or packages to perform different tasks, and one of those packages, ggplot2, allows researchers to create graphs and charts to visualize their findings without having to migrate the data to Excel and build the chart manually.


Here’s an example of R code that loads in data and displays it:

#This is a comment. In this line of code, I'm loading a dataset called mtcars.
data(mtcars)

#This line of code prints the first few rows of the mtcars dataset.
head(mtcars)

                   mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb
Mazda RX4         21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46  0  1    4    4
Mazda RX4 Wag     21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02  0  1    4    4
Datsun 710        22.8   4  108  93 3.85 2.320 18.61  1  1    4    1
Hornet 4 Drive    21.4   6  258 110 3.08 3.215 19.44  1  0    3    1
Hornet Sportabout 18.7   8  360 175 3.15 3.440 17.02  0  0    3    2
Valiant           18.1   6  225 105 2.76 3.460 20.22  1  0    3    1




RMarkdown
RMarkdown is a tool that mixes regular text with R code. Think of it as a combination of a word processor and a programming tool that makes it easy to create dynamic and reproducible documents in various formats (PDF, HTML, or Word documents).
Below is an example of RMarkdown. Don’t get caught up in exactly what it means, but do recognize the general syntax pattern.

---
title: "RMarkdown Example"
author: "Your Name"
date: 7/23/2024
---

# Introduction That Will Print in Heading 1 Style

This is a simple example of an RMarkdown document.

## Head of mtcars That Will Print in Heading 2 Style

data(mtcars)
head(mtcars)



RStudio
RStudio is the downloadable software environment used to write code in R and RMarkdown. In RStudio, you can write in R, run code, and view plots all in one place. Think of it as the structure that allows you to use both R and RMarkdown in user-friendly way. See figure 1 below to get a sense of what working in RStudio looks like.




Figure 1



RStudio on Windows Desktop  Source: Author’s screenshot.










Box 1



How R, RMarkdown, and RStudio Work Together


When combined, these tools provide a powerful ecosystem for data analysis, visualization, and reporting.



R is the engine that allows you to write and execute code for data analysis.
RStudio is the environment where you develop and manage your R projects in an organized manner.
RMarkdown is the format you use to create dynamic documents that include both text and R code, making it easy to share your findings in various formats.









For more information about R, visit Urban’s Intro to R resource page here.




LaTeX
LaTeX is a typesetting program using plain text with embedded formatting commands to produce high-quality products, usually in PDF format. It’s useful for scientific and technical writing because it handles complex formatting, like mathematical equations, bibliographies, and citations, more easily than traditional word-processing software.

LaTeX Vs. Word-Processing Software
Instead of clicking buttons to format your document like in word-processing software, you write plain text mixed with special commands that tell LaTeX how to format the text. This reduces formatting, citation, and numbering errors common while using word-processing software, although word-processing software has a much smalller learning curve than LaTeX.


LaTeX Basics


Open RStudio and install a LaTeX distribution. When using LaTeX in

Write the Document

Content is typically in plain text in a .tex file and includes commands to format text. See the example below:



\documentclass{article}
\begin{document}
\title{My LaTeX Document}
\author{John Doe}
\maketitle
\section{Introduction}
This is a LaTeX document. I can write text and include formulas like \( E = mc^2 \).
\end{document}


Run a LaTeX compiler program that reads the .tex file and processes it to produce a formatted PDF. The output is a clean, professional-looking document where all elements are perfectly placed, consistent, and properly formatted.

In this case, it will be the “knitr” compiler in RStudio.





Resources
For more information about LaTeX, visit the LaTeX site here.Currently, Overleaf is the most popular choice for editing LaTeX documents because it allows you to apply track changes easily in various files.



Quarto
Quarto is awesome.
For more information on the basics of R use at Urban, click here. See box 1 for more information.

title: About
text:
Alex Dallman is an editor and developer at the Urban Institute. Before working at Urban, she was the lead academic editor for TypeRight Editing. She received her BA in integrative physiology from the University of Colorado, Boulder, has completed editing courses from the University of Chicago Graham School, and received a graduate-level professional certificate in data analytics from the University of Oregon.     


  500 L’Enfant Plaza SW Washington, DC 20024 www.urban.org 


 About the Urban Institute  The Urban Institute is a nonprofit research organization that provides data and evidence to help advance upward mobility and equity. We are a trusted source for changemakers who seek to strengthen decisionmaking, create inclusive economic growth, and improve the well-being of families and communities. For more than 50 years, Urban has delivered facts that inspire solutions—and this remains our charge today.

Copyright © July 2024. Urban Institute. Permission is granted for reproduction of this file, with attribution to the Urban Institute.

title: R and GitHub for Editors
text:
Summary
The technologies metioned above are interconnected in the world of research, and having base knowledge of how these programs work can help editors better understand researchers’ workflow. To summarize all these concepts, let’s go through a real-world example of how these programs relate to one another.


Write R code in RStudio to analyze your data.
Document your analysis using RMarkdown, incorporating text and code.
Format the document using LaTeX for any complex equations or detailed formatting.
Track changes and collaborate with team members using GitHub, ensuring everyone works on the most recent version.
Compile and publish your final report using Quarto, producing a document ready for publication.


On subsequent pages, you can learn more about how to edit files in different file formats in various programs.

title: Editing Figures in R
text:
Editing Figures in R
Editing figures in R for Urban style can be done quite easily if you know what to look for. The first step is to ask the researcher for the r files associated with the project in a folder (usually an r project folder). The preferred method is opening a new branch on a GitHub repo. For more information on how to make a new branch on an existing repo, see the Using GitHub page. If the researcher only has a local folder saved, you can ask them to send you the zipped project folder via email.
Before you begin, make sure the researcher has used the urbnthemes ggplot2 package for generating the figures.

Opening the R Project
Go to RStudio on your desktop and open the R project via the zipped file or through GitHub. All of the files will open in RStudio in the side panel. Ask the researchers which file has the associated figure that needs editing. Also ask the researcher for the numbered lines of code, so you can navigate to the figure more easily.




Figure 1



RStudio Example  Source: Author’s screenshot. Notes: Highlighted in green are the numbered lines of code. Circled in orange is where you can see all the files in an R project.






What to Look for in the File
Next, you will need to find the figure that needs editing or formatting work. The researcher can point you to those lines of code. The key identifier to look out for is ggplot. The whole code chunk should look something like the block below, which when run, will produce an image like the one on the bottom of the code block.


Code
ggplot(df_fig2_long, aes(x = Category, y = Value, fill = Series)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = position_dodge()) +
  labs(y = "Percent", x = "", fill = "") +
  scale_fill_discrete(labels = c('Current funding and participation', 
                                 'Full funding and participation in SSI, SNAP, WIC, TANF, CCDF, LIHEAP, and housing')) +
  geom_text(aes(label = decimal_to_percentage(Value)), 
            vjust = -0.5, 
            position = position_dodge2(width = 0.7, padding = 0.5),
            size = 2,
            color = "black", 
            family = "Lato") +
  scale_y_continuous(expand = expansion(mult = 0), 
                     limits = c(0, max(df_fig2_long$Value) * 1.5), 
                     labels = decimal_to_percentage) +
  theme_bw() +
  theme(legend.position = "top", 
        legend.justification = "left", 
        legend.margin = margin(t = -8), 
        plot.margin = unit(c(1, 0, 0, 0), "lines"), 
        axis.title.y = element_text(size = 7, family = "Lato", colour = "black"), 
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 8, family = "Lato", colour = "black"), 
        axis.text.y = element_text(size = 8, family = "Lato", colour = "black"), 
        legend.text = element_text(size = 7), 
        legend.title = element_text(size = 7), 
        panel.border = element_blank(), 
        panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), 
        axis.line = element_line(colour = "black")) +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(title = ""))









For reference,here’s what the chart would look like if no theme or style parameters were applied:


Code
ggplot(df_fig2_long, aes(x= Category, y = Value, fill = Series)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") + 
  labs(y = "Percent", x = "", fill = "")











Common Changes to Figures
Below you will find common changes that need to be made to figures and how to change them in RStudio.

Capitalization and hypenation changes in data labels, legend text, and axis text


Color changes for data labels, legend text, and axis text


Low-quality exported images


Positioning of legend



Providing the Researchers with an Updated Figure

R is a programming language used for data analysis and visualization. It was created by statisticians to make the pipeline from raw data to clean visualization and analysis possible.


Analyze data. R helps researchers process and organize datasets, perform statistical analyses, and draw insights from the data.
Visualize results. R can access different types of software or packages to perform different tasks, and one of those packages, ggplot2, allows researchers to create graphs and charts to visualize their findings without having to migrate the data to Excel and build the chart manually.


Here’s an example of R code that loads in data and displays it:

#This is a comment. In this line of code, I'm loading a dataset called mtcars.
data(mtcars)

#This line of code prints the first few rows of the mtcars dataset.
head(mtcars)

                   mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb
Mazda RX4         21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46  0  1    4    4
Mazda RX4 Wag     21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02  0  1    4    4
Datsun 710        22.8   4  108  93 3.85 2.320 18.61  1  1    4    1
Hornet 4 Drive    21.4   6  258 110 3.08 3.215 19.44  1  0    3    1
Hornet Sportabout 18.7   8  360 175 3.15 3.440 17.02  0  0    3    2
Valiant           18.1   6  225 105 2.76 3.460 20.22  1  0    3    1




RMarkdown
RMarkdown is a tool that mixes regular text with R code. Think of it as a combination of a word processor and a programming tool that makes it easy to create dynamic and reproducible documents in various formats (PDF, HTML, or Word documents).
Below is an example of RMarkdown. Don’t get caught up in exactly what it means, but do recognize the general syntax pattern.

---
title: "RMarkdown Example"
author: "Your Name"
date: 7/23/2024
---

# Introduction That Will Print in Heading 1 Style

This is a simple example of an RMarkdown document.

## Head of mtcars That Will Print in Heading 2 Style

data(mtcars)
head(mtcars)



RStudio
RStudio is the downloadable software environment used to write code in R and RMarkdown. In RStudio, you can write in R, run code, and view plots all in one place. Think of it as the structure that allows you to use both R and RMarkdown in user-friendly way. See figure 1 below to get a sense of what working in RStudio looks like.




Figure 1



RStudio on Windows Desktop  Source: Author’s screenshot.










Box 1



How R, RMarkdown, and RStudio Work Together


When combined, these tools provide a powerful ecosystem for data analysis, visualization, and reporting.



R is the engine that allows you to write and execute code for data analysis.
RStudio is the environment where you develop and manage your R projects in an organized manner.
RMarkdown is the format you use to create dynamic documents that include both text and R code, making it easy to share your findings in various formats.









For more information about R, visit Urban’s Intro to R resource page here.




LaTeX
LaTeX is a typesetting program using plain text with embedded formatting commands to produce high-quality products, usually in PDF format. It’s useful for scientific and technical writing because it handles complex formatting, like mathematical equations, bibliographies, and citations, more easily than traditional word-processing software.

LaTeX Vs. Word-Processing Software
Instead of clicking buttons to format your document like in word-processing software, you write plain text mixed with special commands that tell LaTeX how to format the text. This reduces formatting, citation, and numbering errors common while using word-processing software, although word-processing software has a much smalller learning curve than LaTeX.


LaTeX Basics


Open RStudio and install a LaTeX distribution. When using LaTeX in

Write the Document

Content is typically in plain text in a .tex file and includes commands to format text. See the example below:



\documentclass{article}
\begin{document}
\title{My LaTeX Document}
\author{John Doe}
\maketitle
\section{Introduction}
This is a LaTeX document. I can write text and include formulas like \( E = mc^2 \).
\end{document}


Run a LaTeX compiler program that reads the .tex file and processes it to produce a formatted PDF. The output is a clean, professional-looking document where all elements are perfectly placed, consistent, and properly formatted.

In this case, it will be the “knitr” compiler in RStudio.





Resources
For more information about LaTeX, visit the LaTeX site here.Currently, Overleaf is the most popular choice for editing LaTeX documents because it allows you to apply track changes easily in various files.



Quarto
Quarto is awesome.
For more information on the basics of R use at Urban, click here. See box 1 for more information.

What Are R, LaTeX, Quarto, and GitHub?
In research institutions like the Urban Institute, R, LaTeX, Quarto, and GitHub are powerful tools used together or seperately to produce research products efficiency, with reproducibility and presentation in mind. They are all opensource to some degree and R, LaTeX, and Quarto are free to the public at all tiers. Described below is how each piece of the puzzle fits together. Let’s start by looking at figure 1.




Figure 1



How R, RStudio, RMarkdown, LaTeX, Quarto, and GitHub Work Together

R, RMarkdown, and RStudio

R
R is a programming language used for data analysis and visualization. It was created by statisticians to make the pipeline from raw data to clean visualization and analysis possible.


Analyze data. R helps researchers process and organize datasets, perform statistical analyses, and draw insights from the data.
Visualize results. R can access different types of software or packages to perform different tasks, and one of those packages, ggplot2, allows researchers to create graphs and charts to visualize their findings without having to migrate the data to Excel and build the chart manually.


Here’s an example of R code that loads in data and displays it:

Below is an example of RMarkdown. Don’t get caught up in exactly what it means, but do recognize the general syntax pattern.

RStudio
RStudio is the downloadable software environment used to write code in R and RMarkdown. In RStudio, you can write in R, run code, and view plots all in one place. Think of it as the structure that allows you to use both R and RMarkdown in user-friendly way. See figure 2 below to get a sense of what working in RStudio looks like.




Figure 2



RStudio on Windows Desktop  Source: Author’s screenshot.










Box 1



How R, RMarkdown, and RStudio Work Together


When combined, these tools provide a powerful ecosystem for data analysis, visualization, and reporting.



R is the engine that allows you to write and execute code for data analysis.
RStudio is the environment where you develop and manage your R projects in an organized manner.
RMarkdown is the format you use to create dynamic documents that include both text and R code, making it easy to share your findings in various formats.









For more information about R, visit Urban’s Intro to R resource page here.




LaTeX
LaTeX is a typesetting program using plain text with embedded formatting commands to produce high-quality products, usually in PDF format. It’s useful for scientific and technical writing because it handles complex formatting, like mathematical equations, bibliographies, and citations, more easily than traditional word-processing software.

LaTeX Vs. Word-Processing Software
Instead of clicking buttons to format your document like in word-processing software, you write plain text mixed with special commands that tell LaTeX how to format the text. This reduces formatting, citation, and numbering errors common while using word-processing software, although word-processing software has a much smalller learning curve than LaTeX.


LaTeX Basics


Open RStudio and install a LaTeX distribution.
Write the Document.

Content is typically in plain text in a .tex or .rmd file and includes commands to format text. See the example below:



\documentclass{article}
\begin{document}
\title{My LaTeX Document}
\author{John Doe}
\maketitle
\section{Introduction}
This is a LaTeX document. I can write text and include formulas like \( E = mc^2 \).
\end{document}


Run a LaTeX compiler program that reads the .tex and .rmd files and processes them to produce a formatted PDF. The output is a professional-looking document in which all elements are perfectly placed, consistent, and properly formatted.

In this case, it will be the “knitr” compiler in RStudio.





Resources
For more information about LaTeX, visit the LaTeX site here. Currently, Overleaf is the most popular choice for editing LaTeX documents because it allows you to apply track changes easily in various files.



Quarto
Quarto is a tool that helps people create professional documents, presentations, websites, and more. It combines text, data, code, and graphics into a single, polished output.


Writing Content

Quarto uses Markdown, and RMarkdown in RStudio.

Code and Data

Code snippets from languages like R, Python, or Julia can allow users to embed data analysis directly within your document.

Rendering

Quarto runs the code, captures the outputs (like graphs and tables), and formats everything according to your specifications, producing PDFs, HTML files, Word documents, PowerPoint presentations, and even websites.




Quarto vs. LaTeX
Quarto and LaTeX are similar, but there are key differences. See table 1 for more information.



Table 1: Quarto vs. LaTeX










Feature
Quarto
LaTeX




Ease of use
Easier, uses Markdown
More difficult, uses LaTeX


Integration
Combines text, code, and visualizations
Focused on text and formatting


Output formats
PDF, HTML, Word, PowerPoint
Primarily PDF


Code embedding
Supports embedding R, Python, Julia code
Requires external tools for code integration


Collaboration
Integrates with GitHub for version control
Can be used with GitHub, but less integrated


Flexibility
Great for interactive and static documents
Best for static documents








Source: Author’s analysis.


To understand more about Quarto, visit their website here.



GitHub
GitHub is a web-based platform used for collaborative software developmenta and version-control system that tracks changes in files and coordinates work on those files among multiple people.

GitHub Basics
Researchers and data scientists use GitHub throughout the lifecycle of a project to house all the various R, RMarkdown, LaTeX, and other associated files. It’s like Box but for more code-based work (but any type of file can be uploaded to GitHub).


Repository (Repo). A repository is like a project’s folder on GitHub. It contains all the project files and the history of changes to those files.
Commits. A commit is like a snapshot of a project, representing a set of changes made to the files in a repository.
Branches. Branches allow users to work on different parts of a project separately. A branch can develop a new feature while the main branch contains the stable version of the project.


See figure 3 below.




Figure 3
